texts.definition: The goal of freeing someone or something that is guarded or otherwise not free to move by its own will.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal of freeing someone or something that is guarded or otherwise not free to move by its own will.</style>

A common plot in games is that an opponent has captured or imprisoned a character that players' characters know or they care about. This gives players <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals, which may consist of finding the location of the kidnapped character as well as overcoming or avoiding the obstacles and enemies on the way there. Games using <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> as the main goal often have the opponent as the final enemy that has to be defeated before completing the goal.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Donkey%20Kong">Donkey Kong</link></style> and the games in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> have goals for Mario to <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> a kidnapped girl, princess peach in the case of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>.

Some missions in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> missions for the counter-terrorist teams (the terrorists need to guard them for a certain amount of time).

Characters killed in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> respawn, but can only actually re-enter the game if other players rescue them from the closets and other small areas in which they appear. Active characters can also need rescuing - those that have fallen of ledges or pounced on by "hunters" cannot get out of their trouble on their own.

There are two main ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals. First, something in a game may be suffering from <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>. Second, they can be designed by creating explicit goals in which <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals are assigned to <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> (which may be players) and then giving others the goals and means of freeing that which is guarded. Typical, what needs rescuing is a <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Character</link></style> which may or may not be an <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style>, but in some cases players' <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> can work even though this may give these players <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>; when the gameplay involving the <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> is frantic in some aspect, this may lead to <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with the pattern having the <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> pattern.

The means of fulfilling <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals are typically being able to engage successfully in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> with the guards or being able to avoid this by succeeding with <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> goals. <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals can also be implicit, here the <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals (and the guards) only need to be diegetically hinted at, and the pattern itself takes on aspects of narration and theme rather than gameplay.

Several patterns can be used to make <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals more challenging or complex. <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> can make the process generally longer or more difficult, while <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> can be suitable if the <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals should be finales of games or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals can be required to localize those that need rescuing and be part of the rewards for completing the <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style>. <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals can also be coupled to <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals as <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> related the locations of <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> that could make the <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> more difficult. Further challenges can be added by ensuring that <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> attempts are noticed as some point, e.g. when they have succeeded by those involved have not yet reached safe areas; this since they can open up for <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> goals of those that had the original <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals and their allies.

<style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals are often used as part of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> in a game, and they make easy starting points for creating <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. When doing so, they also support <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can be built from the pattern, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can also provide information and motivation for the pattern.

<style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals are <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> since they are defined by <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals to agents with <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals, making <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> and <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style>. The exception to this is when the people guarding are only implied through narration and cannot actually try to hinder players during gameplay. Although the goal object of <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals may be <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, possibly controlled by other players, the structure of <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals can in many cases be seen as struggles over <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> (e.g., the missions in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> with hostages).

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Rescue</style> goals on players so that they become the ones that need to be rescued requires applying the <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style> pattern on them.
